articles.headline: As U.S. Confronts Internet’s Disruptions, China Feels Vindicated
articles.snippet: It censors online expression, but it has also taken a hard line against fake news, hacking and deception.
articles.abstract: It censors online expression, but it has also taken a hard line against fake news, hacking and deception.
articles.lead_paragraph: HULUNBUIR, China — In the United States, some of the world’s most powerful technology companies face rising pressure to do more to fight false information and stop foreign infiltration.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: The Free Meal, Long Gone, Returns on Some Airlines
articles.snippet: Complimentary food, along with Wi-Fi and free entertainment, is an indication of the airlines’ emergence from hard economic times.
articles.abstract: Complimentary food, along with Wi-Fi and free entertainment, is an indication of the airlines’ emergence from hard economic times.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed to be extinct. The airlines stopped offering it on domestic flights more than a decade ago, along with other amenities that once made air travel an adventure rather than an endurance test. And yet it has reappeared in recent months: a free meal in coach.

articles.headline: Trump and McConnell Strive for Comity Amid Rising Tensions
articles.snippet: President Trump and Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, put on a public display of bonhomie, waving aside reports of a disintegrating relationship.
articles.abstract: President Trump and Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, put on a public display of bonhomie, waving aside reports of a disintegrating relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, tried to convey a sense of harmony on Monday after months of bitter, private feuding that threatened to undermine their party’s legislative push in the coming weeks to enact a sweeping tax cut.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: How Valuable Is a Unicorn? Maybe Not as Much as It Claims to Be
articles.snippet: A new study by a pair of professors concludes that many so-called unicorn companies are worth half of what is commonly reported for their valuation.
articles.abstract: A new study by a pair of professors concludes that many so-called unicorn companies are worth half of what is commonly reported for their valuation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber is said to be worth $62.5 billion. Airbnb is valued at $31 billion. Elon Musk’s SpaceX Technologies is valued at $21 billion, and Pinterest at $12.3 billion.

articles.headline: Harvey Weinstein’s Fall Opens the Floodgates in Hollywood
articles.snippet: With women in the entertainment industry leading the discussion, talk of sexual harassment floods social media.
articles.abstract: With women in the entertainment industry leading the discussion, talk of sexual harassment floods social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Harvey Weinstein is certainly not the first powerful man publicly and credibly accused of sexually harassing or abusing women in recent years.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Rachel Abrams and Melena Ryzik

articles.headline: Why Investors Can’t Get Enough of Tajikistan’s Debt
articles.snippet: Risky bonds issued by poorer countries are all the rage among investors. Some bankers worry the frenzy will end badly.
articles.abstract: Risky bonds issued by poorer countries are all the rage among investors. Some bankers worry the frenzy will end badly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, it’s been a rite of autumn: Finance ministers and central bankers from economically struggling countries arrive here for the International Monetary Fund’s meetings, seeking cash infusions or bailouts from the world’s richest nations.

articles.headline: Raqqa, ISIS ‘Capital,’ Is Captured, U.S.-Backed Forces Say
articles.snippet: Loss of the Syrian city is a heavy blow to the militants, but the destruction there is immense, and questions linger about who will govern and rebuild.
articles.abstract: Loss of the Syrian city is a heavy blow to the militants, but the destruction there is immense, and questions linger about who will govern and rebuild.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — American-backed forces said on Tuesday that they had seized the northern Syrian city of Raqqa from the Islamic State, a major blow to the militant group, which had long used the city as the de facto capital of its self-declared caliphate.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Why the Trade Deficit Matters, and What Trump Can Do About It
articles.snippet: Economists may argue that trade deficits are ultimately irrelevant. But they have wounded American workers.
articles.abstract: Economists may argue that trade deficits are ultimately irrelevant. But they have wounded American workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump surely remembers when Japan was eating America’s lunch.
